title: Venezuela: Citi Launches Fourth Annual "My Sustainable Business" Program
summary: Caracas, Venezuela - One hundred and twenty people, most of them heads of household, attended My Sustainable Recycling Business, a forum held in Caracas on October 31. The program offers environmental and financial education with the goal of helping participants start their own businesses, exposing them to cases of Venezuelan entrepreneurs who have succeeded through projects based on recycling.
tag-1: Venezuela: Citi Launches Fourth Annual "My Sustainable Business" Program
tag-3: Caracas, Venezuela – One hundred and twenty people, most of them heads of household, attended My Sustainable Recycling Business, a forum held in Caracas on October 31. The program offers environmental and financial education with the goal of helping participants start their own businesses, exposing them to cases of Venezuelan entrepreneurs who have succeeded through projects based on recycling.
tag-4: The forum is part of a project by Citi and its NGO partner, PROVITA, designed to promote economic development and social well-being in disadvantaged communities by devoting efforts and resources to creating and strengthening environmentally sustainable micro businesses.
tag-5: Program beneficiaries will learn to reuse waste materials in ingenious and creative ways to make a variety of products, and will develop a business plan for bringing the products to market.
tag-6: According to Nelson Acosta, president of Citi Venezuela, the program develops entrepreneurial skills through financial education, financial management advice, and skills and leadership training. "By the end of the process, individuals and communities are empowered through active participation and the experience of success. Our goal is to promote employment opportunities and contribute to the sustainable development of their environment."
tag-7: More than 450 people have benefited from the program since 2010 in the municipalities of Libertador and Sucre, thanks to Citi's Bs 1.05 million investment. Participants learned to make purses, wallets, cases, cards and other products from recycled paper and cloth. The next phase of the program aims to train more than 180 people and promote environmental awareness among 800 more.
tag-8: "Beneficiaries received business training, not only in processing waste materials but also in acquiring financial and management skills, knowledge they can use in whatever activity they decide to pursue," commented Diego Giraldo Hernández, Senior Advisor at PROVITA.
tag-9: The program has been expanded in 2013-2014 to reach the entire capital area. The forum is the first in a series of activities that will include more than 14 entrepreneurship and recycling workshops; a Christmas fair to sell products to the public; an art exhibit inspired by nature and recycling; an Eco-Fair featuring institutions involved in recycling; and microcredit and awards recognizing the participants who develop the best business plans.
